The Dark Castle
Strong drink is raging.
Prov. 20 1
Behold, a castle in our midst
And dark its portals are:
Strong drink is written on its gates
And Many Enter there.
The Demon sits upon his throne
And rules with pitiless hand:
To wrench the joys of home & heart
And shadow all the land.

The castle has no happy hearts.
For joy it does not bring:
It offers but the cup of drink
That hides a deadly sting.
We cannot count the captives there
Within the castle gates:
And who are held by love of drink
Where woe & death awaits.
The castle has its revels dark,
Its oft-repeated fray:
Its bitter curse: its lifted hand,
Whel life is swept away:
The castle has its broken hearts:
Its bitter tears of woe:
Its awful deeds & reunited souls
As all its records show.

Oh, ye who love the temprance cause,
Arise! for duty calls:
Arise! & storm the castle dark-
Its turrets & its walls.
Break down the barriers in the way,
And there, step boldly in:
To rescue Those in peril there,
Around the cups of sin.
Give cheer to all who sorrow there,
And bid them hope again:
And show the Demon on His throne,
That he must cease to reign.
There, strike for God: for truth & right:
And let your blows resound:
Nor falter til the castle walls
Are level with the ground!
E.A. Barnes.

The Day is Ended.
The day is ended & I rest
From weary task & care:
To meditate O Lord on thee,
Whose gifts I freely share.
The holy name in light & love
To guide me in Thy ways:
And so I lift, O Lord, to them
My evening hymns of praise.
The day is ended, & I read
The Word That is divine:
It sweetly speaks, O Lord of Thee
And to this sul of mine.
I kneel to lift my evening prayer
On wings of faith & love: 
Tis sweet to ask, O Lord of Thee,
Who answers from above.

The day is ended & tis sweet
To praise & read & pray:
Rejoice still, O Lord in Thee
The guardian of my way.
I lay me down in peace to sleep
Amid the shades of night
I trust myself, O Lord to thee
Until the morning light.
E.A. Barnes

Drink No More

Drink no more my friend
From the cup of sin:
For  words can never tell.
All the woe therein
Death is in The cup.
That too many seek:
Then, heed the warning words
That to you I speak-
Drink no more!

Drink no more my friend.
Tis a deadly thing:
It gives a rudy gleam
But is a bitter sting.
'Tis the bane of life:
'Tis a curse indeed:
Oh do not turn away
So with you I plead-
Drink no more!

Drink no more my friend
Share an awful fate
And break from fetters dark
Ere it be too late.
Look to God for help:
Sign the pledge to-day:
And heed my warning words,
Heed them all I pray-
Drink no more!
E.A. Barnes.

Early Prayer.
Long ere the silent night,
Fades out before the day;
The Savior, as with burdened soul,
Goes forth alone to pray.
He seeks a quiet spot,
He meets the Father there;
And lo! amid the solitude,
Lifts up an early prayer.
Since Jesus came to be
A pattren and a guide;
This instance is a lesson sweet -
Too sweet to put aside.

It teaches one and all.
'Mid daily toil and care;
That they begin each coming day,
By seeking Good in prayer.
E. A. Barnes,

The Eye of God.
" "
The eye of God. It looketh down
From yonder throne of light;
It taketh note of what we do,
And keeps us in its sight.
There's not a spot on land or sea,
Beneath the boundless sky;
Where we may turn and thus escape
From God's all-seeing eye.

When we are led to do the wrong,
However small the deed;
There's stern displeasure in the eye,
And which 'tis well to heed.
Where we are led to do the right,
And thus His words obey;
There's sweet approval in the eye,
That beams upon our way.
The eye of God. It taketh not.
Of all our actions here;
It seeth what we are at heart,
And not as we appear.
Then, let the record of our life
Be good and bright and true;
Since in the searching eye of God,
'Tis held in constant view.
E.A. Barnes.

"I 'am twenty-one" a young man said,
"And my heart is light and free,
To-day I start on the journey of life,
To solve what it has for me."
[erased- "] An old man heard these hopeful words,

Before you start on the journey of life,

"Life does not always hold its spring,
For there comes the autumn day;
How youth will fade and the circling years
Will render you old and gray."

"The path's not always rough and dark,
No more than 'tis smooth and bright,
To-day you will walk where the shadows lie,
But to-morrow in the light."

To the depths of sin and woe."
"But put your trust in God, my son,
And cherish the good and true,
Then His hand will bless and your soul shall live,
For above the vaulted blue."

God speed the Temperance Cause.
God speed the temperance cause,
With His sustaining hand,
That it may do a noble work
Throughout the land.
It aims to help + bless;
It seeks to lift + save
Deluded ones from that sad fate,
A drunkard's grave.
Behold the bitter tears;
The crime, the want + woe,
That cometh from the course of drink--
Life's darkest foe.

See, honor, wealth & home,
Hope, life & happiness,
That drifting on are lost beneath
That dark abyss.
And hear the orphan's cry;
The beggar's bitter tale;
And what is deeper, sadder still-
A woman's wail.
God speed the temperance cause,
And bless it, far & near,
Until the tyrant of the land
Shall disappear
E.A. Barnes.

Going Home
"I am going home," a school-boy said,
As he left his tasks at school.
"To the cottage white on a quiet street.
To the circle of home that is still complete.
And with love for its golden rule."
"I am going home," a captain said,
As his ship sped o'er the sea,
"To the red farm-house on the lone hillside,
To the sweet village belle, my own promised bride,
And who is now waiting for me."
"I am going home," a merchant said,
As he left the busy street,
"To the "marble front," on a handsome square,
To my wife, as its queen, in her beauty fair,
And my daughters, so gay & sweet."

"I am going home," a woodman said,
As he left his fallen tree.
"To the humble cot just over the hill.
Where my life floweth on like a gentle rill,
With the loved ones so dear to me."
"I am going home," a soldier said,
As he left the battle plain.
"To the dear old home in a northern state,
Where to-day, in their love, all my dear ones wait.
Who will welcome me back again."
"I am going home," a Christian said,
As his life was well nigh o'er,
"To my Father's house by the crystal sea,
For the crown & the robe there waiting for me,
And to wear them forever more."
E.A. Barnes.

Hope.
Hope soothes the sad + anxious heart,
With welcome words of cheer;
It lifts the shadows from the way,
And dries the falling tear. 
Hope helps us in our daily toil
It makes us brave + strong:
It sings within the waiting soul,
A sweet + happy song.
Hope paints the sky of coming days,
With colors rich + rare;
It thickly stews the onward path,
With flowers sweet + fair.

Hope comes amid our rising fears,
And calms them all to rest;-
There is for all a solace sweet,
In hoping for the best. 
Indeed, we must be sinking low,
While drifting o'er the wave;
When we possess no hope in life-
No hope beyond the grave!
E. A. Barnes.

"Only a Dream."
"Only a dream;" but I saw a face, - 
A face that was faire & sweet;
With its starry eyes, & its brow of snow;
While a look of love that I could not know,
Made its glory all complete, - 
"Only a dream."
"Only a dream;" but I saw a form, - 
A form that was wondrous fair,
With its wealth of grace & its drapery white.
And my heart went out to the vision bright,
As it floated through the air, - 
"Only a dream."

"Only a dream," but I heard a voice,
As if from the dark beyond:
It was soft and low, as a murmuring sea,
It was strangely sweet as it called to me,
But my lips could not respond, -
"Only a dream."
"Only a dream:" but I saw a smile,
As in dreams we only see:
And it so softly broke o'er the wondrous face,
Then, it faded out in the realms of space,
And the dream was lost to me, -
"Only a dream."
E. A. Barnes.

The Orphan
I have lost my gentle mother,
And my heart is sad, to-day;
While she sweetly rests in Heaven,
When all tears are wipes away.
Words could never tell my sorrow,
O'er the loss that I sustain;
And in all the years before me,
I shall feel its bitter pain.
Wise & sweet were all the counsels,
That my mother did impart;
And her voice, so soft and loving,
Lingers in my lonely heart.

Oft in dreams, I see my mother,
Radiant with the joys above:
And she seems to call & beckon,
To her home of peace & love.
Oft I seek the village church-yard,
When the veil of night appears:
And above her grave I scatter
Flowers sweet, amid my tears.
Filial ties are often severed,
As its sheaves the Angel reaps,
And I pray, when life has faded - 
Lay me where my mother sleeps!
E. A. Barnes.

Up there in the maple, just ready to sing.
Your coming is timely, this beautiful morn,
When Nature's rejoicing, that Winter has gone.
And so, mid the leaf-lets, that glisten with dew,
A welcome, sweet robin - a welcome to you.
Sing, sing, pretty robin, your happiest lay,
And may your repeat it, for many a day.

That swells, in its sweetness, your beautiful throat.
Mid flowers and sunshine, so pleasant to see,
Your song, pretty robin, comes sweetly to me.

A Strong Resemblance. 
A young lady & her mischievous brother were sitting to-gether on the front veranda of their father's country residence. It was early evening in mid-summer; & they were enjoying the dreamy shadows which were mystically gathering around them. At length, amid their pleasant conversation, & with a sudden burst of rural enthusiasm, the young lady exclaimed: - "Oh, how I love the twilight hour! It is so sweet & refreshing." "You have expressed my sentiments to the letter." responded her companion. "But, my dear sister," he added, with mock gravity. "Can you tell me in what manner the letter L in the word twilight resembles the nose on your sweet face?"

"No, indeed!" she replied, with a certain dignity which she did not feel. "But, no doubt, 'tis a specimen of boyish nonsense." 
"Call it hard names, if you will; but it never the less bears a very strong resemblance. I assure you." was the pleasant response. "
Pray, tell me in what respect," she continued, becoming interested in spite of herself. "I am sure I could never solve your conundrums; & our present weather is too oppressive for much mental exertion." 
"That is the fact; &

"Proceed, then, if you please."
"The solution is simply this" said the ingenious brother, still assuming an air of mock dignity.  "Because the letter L, poor thing! in the word twilight, has its location between two ages."
As he gave this very conclusive explanation, there was a merry sparkle in his own dark eye.  His young sister noticed this; but she said nothing.  She sat & thought for a second, or two, revolving in her mind the word in question.  A perceptible smile then gathered around her lips; for she was forced to acknowledge to herself, that between the two similes there was indeed a very strong resemblance.
E. A. Barnes.

When I enter the great Hereafter, I shall, no doubt, leave behind me a number of hymns & songs -- more, or less, old & new; & some better than others. A Heart's Secret.
I have a secret,
Down in my depths, in silence hidden:
Which makes one spot in life,
A shadowed spot, where light is all forbidden.
And I am silent - 
As silent as the grave about it:
Oh! vainly do I strive,
To free myself that I may live without it.
God knows my secret,
Whose eye is deep, stern & all-seeing:
He knows the pointed steel
That enters deep my life & inmost being.

I muse upon it
With sadness deep & bitter sighing;
For hope, it never came,
And wishes sweet were very quick in dying.
'Tis not a passion,
That would disgrace me, did I name it;
Nor is it yet a crime,
That justice stern should come & sternly claim it.
I guard my secret,
With zealous care & stern suppression -
No look, nor word, nor act,
Must whisper forth a sweet, but sad confession.

It may be weakness,
Set with the seal of secret folly;
And yet it has the germ,
Of what in life is beautiful & holy.
Some hearts would pity,
If I should speak & thus confess it;
Their pity might be sweet;
But secret pride had rather not possess it.
And some would scorn me,
With bitter scorn & pitiless wonder,
If I should lay it out,
For them to probe, & then to coldly ponder.

'Tis hard to suffer,
For what I know cannot be given: -
Cannot be my mine to prize,
No more than earth could touch the arch of Heaven.
But ask! - my secret, -
An arrow keen from Fate's dark giver,
Shall slumber in the dust,
When I in soul pass o'er the Silent River.
E. A. Barnes.

Faded and Gone.
Faded and gone.  These are simple words, but at the present season they contain a deep meaning, and to me they are plainly written on Nature's expansive brow.  To a mediative mind they visibly appear on every side, and they seem to whisper the mournful truth that autumn sad, sighing autumn -- has faded and gone.
Like a spirit bearing in its mystic grasp the shadowy scepter of decay, it succeeded the silent departure of summer; and like a spirit it has completed its mission of blight and then vanished.  Mystically it has sliced behind the viewless vail of the dying year, where it is now mouldering with the sweet ashes of its vernal and flowery precedents.

Once more "the golden pomp of autumn" has made its annual visit to our fruitful land: such it has thrown its glorious mantle of many hues over valley, plain and hillside, both far and near.  The sweet flowers have drooped and faded on every hand; and as the blighting winds have robbed them of their fragrance, and laid them low in the dust, they have borne the beautiful impress of withered beauty.  The luxuriant foliage that for many weeks has yielded us a leafy shade, has exchanged its "living green" for the rich tints of gold, brown and crimson -- the glory of autumnal blight.  Softly they have fallen around us: rudely we have crushed their livid colors beneath our careless tread, while native branches overhead sway mournfully to and fro in the chilly wind, and in their blighted condition they appear

bleak and naked even in the bright sunshine.
The face of nature broad and goodly, has lost that warm, genial, smiling aspect, which is so pleasant and so peculiar to the gentle and flowing reign of the departed seasons.  Silently the blighting months of the sear and yellow leaf have glided over to comely features on the never ceasing wings of time: and as the changing days go swiftly by, they become less attractive and more dreary.  Though the far-off wolkin is often clear blue, it has lost its misty and placid serenity of summer skies, while the pure breezes are no longer sweet, soft and balmy: bracing and invigorating as they certainly are, their breath is nevertheless cold and chilly, for it issues from the icy lips of the wintry monarch that is even now wandering through the land with its trailing robe of frost and snow.

The twittering birds, that for many long and pleasant weeks have sung so sweetly around us, have now deserted their Northern haunts.  Back to the Sunny South -- their winter's home -- the feathered songsters have taken an arrowy flight in large numbers: and we shall not see or hear them again until their tiny throats shall welcome with strains of vernal joy the coming spring.
The merry work of the reaper is now completed, and the harvest days are over.  Once again the fields of grain have ripened in the mellow autumn sunshine: and once again the sturdy sons of the soil have garnered the pearly sheaves and golden fruits that the friendly earth yields annually to the good of all mankind.

Spring and summer came and went on mystic wings; and now their successor autumn -- sweet, drooping, melancholy autumn -- replete with mellow fruits, sighing winds, and the many gorgeous beauties of decay, has softly and dreamily disappeared, taking the viewless path of its gentle precedents, as the four seasons go "marching on."

She also pleads that the strengthened & comforted heart be lifted with gratitude to Him, who has not only written such precious words & unfailing promises, but who graciously gives them as a free gift to His children. How Nellie was Answered
"Grandfather," said Nellie, kneeling down at the old man's feet, "I have just been reading where it speaks very strongly with regard to the relative merits prayer and faith." "Have you, indeed, my child?" he returned, with parental interest, and resting his hand tenderly upon the youthful head before him. "Yes," said Nellie, and then adding in a low voice, "you know, dear grandfather, that I am now endeavoring to lead a Christian noble life, and for this reason I greatly need and desire the benefit of your opinion upon this subject - prayer and faith." "Ah, my daughter," answered the aged follower of that which is good, "these simple forms of individual devotion, by which we draw

near to God, are indeed very sweet to possess, and also very effectual in their united elements. The Bible, which is a sacred history of ancient events, is not by any means, the only source from which we may always gather those incidents of deep interest where the secret soul, with unwavering faith in God, has cried out Him for shingi(?) in time of need. Our every day life, were it now generally known, would reveal a vast number of such instances, and we have the sweet assurance that He both hears and will surely answer in due season the soul's most fervent petition. Therefore, the earnest Christian, as he journeys the way of life, amid so many varied scenes of trial and temptation, cannot cherish these sweet privileges with too much reverence or appreciation. Prayer may be regarded as an invisible chariot, that is ready at all times and under all circumstances to waft the troubled soul up to the portale of of Heaven; and faith, as its inseparable attendant, is the magic key

which unlocks those shining portals, that the soul may enter in and plead its own supplication at the throne of God."
And in this way Nellie was answered.

The Two Teamsters.
One pleasant morning in early summer, I stood at the front gate of a pretty cottage, where I then made it my home.  The little dwelling was situated upon a quiet street; and within the suburbs of a great city.  The soft beauty of the morning had lured me from my study for a few moments; and I had listlessly wandered out to the wicket gate of my temporary home.
As I stood there, enjoying the balmy breeze, I discovered in the misty distance, two stout teams, slowly approaching along the dusty road.  Their respective teamsters were rough looking fellows; and the lumbering wagons were heavily loaded with stone.
When the teams in question were nearly opposite the gate where I was standing, the foremost driver -- the younger of the two men

-- reined in his steady horses, and came to a stand-still.
"Hallo, there, you youngster!" cried the driver in the rear, in loud and surly tones, as his own team very naturally halted; "what are you stopping for?"
"To let me horses take breath for a minute," replied the young teamster, descending from his stony seat, and brushing, with his hard hand, the loose dust from the warm flanks of the nearest horse.
"The beasts don't want to take breath; so drive on, and don't keep a fellow waiting here in the blazin' sun!" said the first speaker, roughly.
"Drive on, yourself, if you want to!" answered his more humane companion.  "My horses are tired and heated; and I'm going to let them rest a little before I start again."  "What!" ejaculated the other, insolently, and with rising anger.  "Do you stand there and think to parley with one in this manner?"

"Drive on, I say!"
"As I am not in your employ, you must not think that I shall obey you in this matter," said the young man.
This quiet and reasonable reply perfectly infuriated the rearward teamster.  His rough, sunburnt features grew crimson, and his eyes flashed fearfully with the fiery passion that he did not make the least attempt to govern or conceal.  With dark threats and darker imprecations upon his lips, he sprang from his wagon, and quickly confronted his more considerate and manly companion.
"Will you drive on, youngsters, without further ado?" he exclaimed, fiercely, as he grasped his offender roughly by the arm.
"Not by your command, sir," replied the youthful teamster, in a fearless tone, and calmly eyeing his unreasonable assailant.

"Shall I strike you?" cried the enraged man, with a bitter oath, and brandishing in the air the heavy whip that he carried in his rough hand.

"Strike me if you will, but I shall not return the first blow," answered the other in fearless tones, "This affair is too trifling to create a quarrel between us on a public street."
"Take that for your impertinence, then!"  With these words, and another fearful oath, the infuriated speaker lifted his whip still higher, and at the same time dealt his more considerate offender a rough blow across his unshrinking shoulders.  True to his word, its manly recipient did not return it; yet there was a peculiar look about him which plainly indicated that he would not suffer as mildly and gently, a second insulting castigation.  As if tho greater portion of

his dark anger had suddenly left him with that unjust chastisement, the impertinent teamster turned roughly away and hastily remounted his hard seat.
Snatching up the reins and applying the whip to his horses, he turned angrily out of the road, and without another word passed on, leaving his companion standing quietly near his own team.  In a moments, however, the latter followed on for it was evident that the two men were drawing stone for the same person or party.
Reader, this little sketch is not entirely a fictitious one -- the golden thread of truth just clearing it, as it were, from the mystic region of fancy.  Trifling as it may seem, it is literally one of those innumerable instances, where the baser passions of the human race are brought in their broadest light by some simple offence; and that without the least regard to the nobler dictates of reason,

self control, and principle, where the sleepless demon of a fiery temper springs up from its lair within the breast: and for a while, mars and defaces, with its reckless incitations, the beautiful image of a man.  Many a heart has in its possession just such a quick, revengeful, passionate temper as that rough teamster manifested; and woe! to that if it is left to its dark and furious tendencies.  Such a temper is a fearful gift; and if not properly governed by one's reason and self-control, it will surely prove the besom of a great evil to its unhappy possessor.
It will in time expel forever from the heart's mystic garden the delicate germ of every pure and holy emotion.
Thousand of incidents similar to the one of which I have spoken, are daily transpiring around us; and alas! too often are
many of them attended by with darker and more debasing consequences than those which resulted from the trivial affair between the two teamsters.

Ripples of Thought
Pity, with its crystal drops, is sweeten-ing many a e..(?) of life. And, in re-turn, many a grateful heart is laying on the palm of pity the choicest gems of gratitude. Good resolutions are an honor to every heart that may form them. But that honor takes to itself a new lustre(?),  & that heart is nobler still when these resolutions are not broken. What We Love to See
We love to see a little child
When old enough to understand,
Reject the wrong & choose the right 
Obeying thus a wise command
We love to see a little child 
Kneel softly down to say its prayer,
To thank the Lord in simple words,
For all His tender love & care.

We love to see a little child, 
Lift up its voice & sweetly sing 
In praise of Him the childrens' Friend
And thus its little tribute bring.
We love to see a little child
Instructed in the holy word 
For such a child in many ways 
Can be of service to the Lord.
E.A.B.
